stimulusHtml:
Complete method  playerWithClosestScore.

 

/**
 *  Returns the ID of the player whose score is closest to
 *  targetScore      
 *  Preconditions: playerList is not null.
 *                 No elements of playerList are null.
 *                 playerList is not empty.
 *  Postcondition: playerList is unchanged.
 */
public String playerWithClosestScore(int targetScore)

features.html:
The  Player  class is used to store information about a player in a video game. A partial declaration of the  Player  class is shown.

 

public class Player
{
   /** 
    *  Returns a unique ID for the player
    */
   public String getID()
   { /* implementation not shown */ }

   /** 
    *  Returns the player’s score in the game,
    *  guaranteed to be nonnegative
    */
   public int getScore()
   { /* implementation not shown */ }

   /* There may be instance variables, constructors, and methods 
      that are not shown. */
}

 

The  PlayerAnalysis  class maintains a list of all players of the game. A partial declaration of the  PlayerAnalysis  class is shown.
 

public class PlayerAnalysis
{
   /** The list of all players */
   private ArrayList<Player> playerList;

   /**
    *  Returns the ID of the player whose score is closest to
    *  targetScore      
    *  Preconditions: playerList is not null.
    *                 No elements of playerList are null.
    *                 playerList is not empty.
    *  Postcondition: playerList is unchanged.
    */
   public String playerWithClosestScore(int targetScore)
   { /* to be implemented */ }

   /* There may be instance variables, constructors, and methods 
      that are not shown. */
}

 

Write the  PlayerAnalysis  method  playerWithClosestScore.  The method should return the ID of the player whose score is closest to the parameter  targetScore.  If multiple players have a score closest to  targetScore,  then any of their IDs can be returned.

 

For example, suppose  playerList  has the following contents.

  • The ArrayList has 6 elements. 

    • The following presents each element’s value, from left to right. The first value is for index 0, the second value is for index 1, and so forth. 

  • Each element has the following attributes:

    • Player ID 

    • Score 

  • The objects in the ArrayList have the following contents: 

    • Index 0: 

      • Player ID: "DJK" 

      • Score: 1090 

    • Index 1: 

      • Player ID: "CJL" 

      • Score: 2800 

    • Index 2: 

      • Player ID: "JOY" 

      • Score: 2000 

    • Index 3: 

      • Player ID: "BEN" 

      • Score: 500 

    • Index 4: 

      • Player ID: "PTT" 

      • Score: 3500 

    • Index 5: 

      • Player ID: "JAY" 

      • Score: 4500

 

For this example,  playerWithClosestScore  should behave as follows.

  • The call  playerWithClosestScore(1000)  should return  "DJK".

  • The call  playerWithClosestScore(2000)  should return  "JOY".

  • The call  playerWithClosestScore(3000)  should return  "CJL".

  • The call  playerWithClosestScore(4000)  should return either  "PTT"  or  "JAY".

  • The call  playerWithClosestScore(5000)  should return  "JAY".
